bestBHT.bht: When our Lord lifted up His eyes and saw at a distance, He observed the people casting money into the treasury. This incident took place as He was departing from the temple and provided a slight diversion from the intense strain of the moments before. Many rich individuals were among those making offerings towards the maintenance of the temple, catching the attention of Jesus as He sat across from the treasury and watched them fervently cast their gifts.

Henry Alford: Our Lord as yet has been surrounded with His disciples...He now lifts up His eyes, and sees at a distance, &c."
He seems to have overlooked the break at ver. 7, corresponding to the change of scene.
Three speak of the opening incident as happening while He was departing from the temple; and St. Matthew and St. Mark, of the enquiry being made afterwards, on the Mount of Olives.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: looking up He saw"—as in Zaccheus' case, not quite casually.
the people," says Mark 12:41 "cast money into the treasury, and many rich east in much
into chests deposited in one of the courts of the temple to receive the offerings of the people towards its maintenance (2 Kings 12:9; John 8:20).
Marvin Vincent: Rich. Standing last and emphatically in the sentence, "Saw them that were casting, etc. - rich men." Not the rich only were casting in. Compare Mark 12:41.
Philip Schaff: From where he had been sitting during the delivery of His denunciatory discourse 'over against the treasury'." - Luke 21:1.
The distance could not have been very great." - Luke 21:1.
Archibald T. Robertson: He had taken his seat, after the debate was over and the Sanhedrin had slunk away in sheer defeat...
The word for 'treasury' is a compound of γαζα (Persian word for royal treasury) and φυλακη guard or protection.
Jesus was watching the rich put in their gifts as a slight diversion from the intense strain of hours before.
John Gill: As Christ sat over against the treasury, looking upon the ground, he lift up his eyes."
The treasury was not in an high place, or above Christ, who was right against it.
He saw the rich men casting their gifts into the treasury.

bhtAttempts.bht: When Jesus lifted up His eyes and saw a distance, He observed the opening incident as He was departing from the temple. He noticed the people casting money into the treasury, specifically many rich individuals. This act of observation provided a slight diversion from the intense strain of the moments before, allowing Jesus to focus on the offerings being made towards the maintenance of the temple. Sitting over against the treasury, He looked upon the ground and then lifted up His eyes, watching the rich men casting their gifts.

As Jesus departed from the temple and lifted up His eyes, He saw the people casting money into the treasury. He observed many rich individuals contributing to the offerings of the temple. This act of observation provided a slight diversion from the intense strain of the moments before, allowing Jesus to focus on the maintenance of the temple. Sitting over against the treasury, He watched the rich men casting their gifts.

As Jesus departed from the temple, He looked up and observed people casting money into the treasury. Many rich individuals were among those making offerings. This momentary diversion allowed Jesus to shift his attention from the intense strain of the moments before and focus on the financial contributions made for the maintenance of the temple. Positioned across from the treasury, Jesus carefully watched as the rich men cast their gifts.

When our Lord lifted up His eyes and saw at a distance, He observed the people casting money into the treasury. This incident took place as He was departing from the temple and provided a slight diversion from the intense strain of the moments before. Many rich individuals were among those making offerings towards the maintenance of the temple, catching the attention of Jesus as He sat across from the treasury and watched them fervently cast their gifts.

As Jesus departed from the temple, He lifted up His eyes and saw at a distance. He observed the people casting money into the treasury, including many rich individuals. This slight diversion allowed Him to momentarily shift his focus from the intense strain of the moments before. Positioned across from the treasury, Jesus carefully watched as the rich men fervently cast their gifts towards the maintenance of the temple.
